column1: Cypress is a city in northwestern Orange County within Southern California. Its population was 47
column2: 802 at the 2010 census.

column1: The first people living in the area now known as Cypress were the Gabrieleno
column2: a Native American tribe of the Tongva people
column3: who were displaced soon after the arrival of the Europeans. The government of Spain then possessed the land until Mexico gained its independence in 1821. Mexico then lost Alta California to the United States during the period following the Bear Flag Revolt and the Mexican–American War.

column1: The original Spanish dons held immense tracts of land throughout California
column2: which were given in lieu of pay to Spanish soldiers. Manuel Nieto was one of the early Spanish dons or landowners in the area. After his death in 1804
column3: his sons retained title to Rancho Los Nietos
column4: but these lands were eventually broken up and distributed among them in 1833 by a grant from the Mexican governor
column7: retained the title to a large portion of his father's original properties in southern California that included the present-day area of Cypress. That land and other Rancho properties were finally sold to the American Abel Stearns
column8: then acquired by the Robinson Trust
column10: which eventually parlayed their holdings into a vast land speculation business.

column1: Cypress originally was nicknamed "Waterville" due to the preponderance of artesian wells in the area
column2: but was incorporated under the name Dairy City in 1956 by local dairy farmers as a means of staving off developers and to preserve their dairies
column3: much like the then-neighboring cities of Dairy Valley in Cerritos and Dairyland in La Palma. After World War II
column5: the land became too valuable for farming or ranching
column6: and the dairies gradually sold out to housing developers during the 1960s
column7: so that by the 1970s no dairies remained. Many of the dairymen moved their operations to Chino
column8: where development is once again pushing them out of the area.

column1: In 1957 local residents voted to change the name of "Dairy City" to "Cypress". The name was taken from Cypress Elementary School (originally built in 1895) which took its name from the Cypress trees planted to protect the schoolhouse from the seasonal Santa Ana winds. Cypress Elementary School also provided the name for new Pacific Electric Railway station on Walker Street at Lincoln Avenue when the Santa Ana Line was completed in 1906
column2: as "Waterville" already had been used elsewhere in the system.

column1: In 1981 the City of Cypress inaugurated an annual birthday celebration for the City. The event
column2: the Cypress Community Festival
column3: currently may be the largest single-day event of its kind in Orange County
column4: California. The Cypress Community Festival is held annually on the 4th Saturday in July at Oak Knoll Park
column5: located adjacent to the Cypress Community Center at 5700 Orange Avenue
column6: between Valley View Street and Walker Avenue.

column1: Cypress is bounded to the north by the city of La Palma
column2: then clockwise by Buena Park

column1: Cypress is adjacent to the Imperial Estates neighborhood of Long Beach and the Coyote Creek bicycle path to the west and is approximately 13 miles (21 km) north of Bolsa Chica.  The closest beach to Cypress is Seal Beach
column2: which is roughly 7.8 miles (12.6 km) away from the center of Cypress. Cypress is less than a 20-minute drive from Long Beach Airport.
